journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Kinematic and dynamic analyses of the multi-actuated mechanical press with parallel topology

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Feng Gao State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China. Email: gaofengsjtu@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article proposes a new type of multi-actuated mechanical press with parallel topology to develop high stamping capacity. Four active limbs actuated by servomotor deliver forces and motions to moving platform, and the passive limbs are driven by moving platform to push or pull the ram. This four-input-single-output system realizes multiple actuations without causing being over-constrained. Due to infinite number of solutions for the inverse kinematics, selection of actuation schemes for given ram trajectories is more crucial. Further, the principle of virtual work is used in the inverse dynamic problem. By choosing the pose variables of moving platform as generalized coordinates to describe the manipulator system, the linear form of dynamic models is derived. A typical deep-drawing process with nominal 25,000 kN capacity and 1200 mm stroke is simulated, and the required driving torques are computed. These performance analyses provide a basis to the design of the control law or the estimation of servomotor parameters for the mechanical press.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For low cost and high productivity, stamping operations are widely used to manufacture products ranging from automotive panels to kitchen sinks. The conventional mechanical press is fast and energy efficient, since the large flywheel may store energy and overcome the peak force. However, as long as parameters of the drive train are determined, they would have a fixed motion curve and could not change their kinematic and dynamic characteristics. Servomechanical presses have programmable stroke and velocity, and are able to dwell in the stroke without energy loss. Moreover, they can offer high productivity, low maintenance, reduced snap-through loads, and low energy costs. For the advantages of servomechanical presses, many research efforts have been focused on the development of servomechanical presses in the last two decades.

Yossifon et al.1 designed a servomotor-driven multi-action press. This prototype connected the ram of the press to a servomotor with a bolt screw mechanism. However, without the mechanical advantage of a linkage mechanism, the torque of the motor required to operate it is still large. Later, they2–4 discussed the analysis, optimization, and design considerations of a double-knuckle mechanical press driven by a servomotor. Yan and Chen5–7 proposed the novel approach of properly designing the input speed to make output motion pass through a desired trajectory using a servomotor as the power input of the press. Hwang8 used a Lagrange multiplier method to synthesize the dimension of drag-link drive mechanical presses for precision drawing. Tso and Liang9 combined the linkage synthesis and the trial and error method to optimize the dimensions of a nine-bar linkage presses. Hsieh and Tsai10 proposed a novel press system with a variable speed coupling (generalized Oldham coupling) and a six-link mechanism for precision deep drawing. Choi et al.11 focused attention on the optimization of the load and velocity characteristics for the linear guide drive mechanical press. Soong12 proposed a design method of speed trajectory and adjustable length of driving links for a single degree of freedom (DoF) mechanical press to obtaining the desired output motion.

However, all the above-mentioned research studies are directed at the single DoF linkage, whose driving torque solely comes from one servomotor. Owing to power limits of the servomotor, the single DoF linkage driven by one servomotor does not suit to the mechanical press with heavy duty. Therefore, hybrid or controllable mechanisms, which are actuated by one ordinary motor and one servomotor, have recently been used in the design of mechanical presses.

Du and Guo13,14 proposed a new type servomechanical press based on hybrid machine concept and developed a hybrid actuation-type servomechanical press prototype with two DoFs seven-bar linkage mechanism. Meng15 studied the inverse kinematic analysis and optimal design of two DoF mechanisms with hybrid input applied to a mechanical press. Li and Tso16 proposed an iterative learning control approach for a hybrid driven press and demonstrated the improvement of pouch position errors and precision through experiments. He et al.17 used the differential gear train as transmission mechanism to study the hybrid problems of the mechanical press. According to the application objective of hybrid mechanism, it can use a constant speed motor with a flywheel to produce majority of the force, and at the same time use a servomotor to tune the performance. How to use the servomotor to control the motion of the punch ram, whose energy is provided by constant speed motor and flywheel, is the key issue of the design of hybrid presses.

For the purpose of developing high-capacity servopress, some press manufacturers have implemented many different approaches18–24 such as high-torque and low-speed servomotors, new driving mechanism with force-multiplier effect and redundant actuation. Here, the redundant actuation means that two or more servomotors were used to drive a single DoF mechanism. Currently, the redundant actuation method in servopresses is mainly executed through two ways. One way is that two or more servomotors independently drive the ram through screw mechanism directly or single DoF linkage mechanism. The other way is that several servomotors drive a common shaft by means of gear mechanism, and then the driven shaft actuates the ram via single DoF linkage mechanism. However, this redundant actuation method must be implemented by the tight motion synchronization of these servomotors. From kinematic point of view, these synchronous actuations are equivalent to one actuation. And then, the ram or shaft with single DoF is fully constrained. If the motion synchronization was not strictly guaranteed, the ram or shaft is over-constrained. In a sense, the over-constrained is caused by redundant actuation. Moreover, this redundant actuation increases the chance of generating internal forces between links, controlling these actuators generally becomes more challenging.

In view of the development of high-capacity mechanical presses, this article proposes a new type of mechanical press with parallel topology. Four servomotors actuate different limbs of parallel mechanism to realize the multiple actuations without causing being over-constrained. The rest of this article is organized as follows. First, the mechanical press with multiple actuations is described. Then, the inverse kinematics is explained under the condition that the pose variables of moving platform are selected as generalized coordinates to describe the manipulator system. Moreover, the principle of virtual work25–29 is used to calculate the driving torque, and the linear form of dynamic models are derived using the concept of link Jacobian matrix presented in the study of Wang and Gosselin.26 A typical deep-drawing process with nominal 25,000 kN capacity and 1200 mm stroke is simulated and the required driving torques are computed. These performance analyses provide a basis to design of the control law or the estimation of servomotor parameters for the mechanical press.

sec.title: Description of the press with parallel topology
sec.p:
A three-dimensional (3D) model and schematic of the mechanical press being considered is shown in Figure 1, which consists of two kinds of limbs, that is, the active limb with RRPaR chain and the passive limb. The passive limb consists of two symmetrically assembled toggle linkage mechanisms with identical structure. Because of the constraint of symmetrical arrangement, the point B5 has the same motion characteristics as the ram. Therefore, the structure of passive limb is equivalent to PRPaR chain. Here, P, R, and Pa denote prismatic, revolute, parallelogram composite joints, respectively. The axes of revolute joints at points Ai and Ei (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) are all parallel and lie on a plane attached to the fixed platform and moving platform, respectively. There is an offset between the parallelogram assembly and the axes of the revolute joints at Bi and Ei. It is noted that the axis of revolute joint at point E5 is coplanar and parallel with those of Ei. The active limbs driven by actuators deliver forces and motions to moving platform, and the passive limbs are driven by moving platform to push or pull the ram. Figure 1.
3D model (a) and schematic (b) of the mechanical press with multiple actuations.

Since each limb in a parallel mechanism imposes one or more constraints to the moving platform, the mobility of the moving platform is determined by the combination of the constraints imposed by the limbs. According to the arrangement of limbs and joints, the revolute joints in Pa are perpendicular to x-axis and other revolute joints always remain parallel to x-axis. The Pa does not affect the orientation of the moving platform. Hence, the combination of four active limbs and one passive limb constrain the rotation of the moving platform with respect to y- and z-axes leaving the moving platform with three translational DoFs and one rotational DoF about x-axis. It is noted that the DoFs of moving platform is the same as the number of the actuators. Therefore, four active limbs satisfy the need to completely specify the mechanism and no actuation redundancy happens.

The usefulness of parallel mechanisms in mechanical presses is to solve the over-constrained problem caused by multiple actuators driving the common ram. Due to the difference existing among the dynamic characteristics of each servomotor, the errors in the position control cannot be avoided in practice, especially in case of high speed or large inertia. For the mechanical press with parallel topology proposed in this manuscript, the motion errors among actuators lead the change of pose of moving platform. As the passive limb, the motion of the ram is decided by the pose of moving platform. Due to the high precision of servomotors, the motion error of the ram can be controlled under a permitted limit. Consequently, the over-constrained problem is solved and the interference among actuators is avoided. From this respect, this mechanical press with parallel topology provides a feasible solution to develop multi-actuation servopress.

sec.title: Inverse kinematics
sec.p: For the purpose of analysis, the following coordinate systems are defined. A global coordinate system O-xyz is attached to the fixed platform, the x-axis is parallel to the axes of revolute joints Ai, the z-axis points downward along the vertical direction. The coordinate of Ai is (xAi, yAi, 0), where xA1 = xA4, xA2 = xA3, yA1 = −yA4, yA2 = −yA3, and yA1 − yA2 = yA3 − yA4 = ε (ε ≠ 0). A moving coordinate frame O1–x1y1z1 is located at the moving platform such that its origin is located at point E5, the x1-axis is coincident with the axis of revolute joints E5, the y1-axis is coplanar with points Ei. The coordinate of Ei expressed in O1–x1y1z1 coordinate system is (1xEi,1yEi,0), where 1xE1 = 1xE4,1xE2 = 1xE3,1yE1 = −1yE4,1yE2 = −1yE3, and1yE1 −1yE2 = 1yE3 −1yE4 = ε (ε ≠ 0). Due to the sliding ram has only one translational DoF along the vertical direction, another moving coordinate frame O2–x2y2z2 is attached to the sliding ram with the same orientations as O–xyz. The origin of frame O2 is located at the center of the upper plane of sliding ram, and denoted as (0, 0, z2) relative to the O–xyz coordinate system.

As shown in Figure 2(a), The pose of the moving platform can be described by a position vector, rO1=[x1 y1 z1]T, and a rotation matrix. Since the moving platform can rotate about x-axis only, the rotation matrix is (1)ORO1=Rot(x,θ6)=[1000cθ6-sθ60sθ6cθ6] where sθ and cθ denotes the sine and cosine of angle θ, respectively. The angular velocity of the moving platform is given by ωO1=[θ·6 0 0]T. The pose of moving platform in coordinate system O–xyz can be expressed by four independent parameters x1, y1, z1, and θ6. Thus, the pose of moving platform is expressed as a vector q = [x1 y1 z1 θ6]T. In this study, the above four independent parameters x1, y1, z1, and θ6 are chosen as generalized coordinates. Figure 2.
Vector diagram of the kinematic limbs.

The orientation of each kinematic link except the link CiDi in planar four-bar parallelogram with respect to the fixed platform can be described by one angle about x-axis, as shown in Figure 2. So, the rotation matrix of the link can be written as (2)oRlink=Rot(x,θlink)=[1000cθlink-sθlink0sθlinkcθlink] where θlink denotes the angle measured from y-axis. Especially, the rotation matrix of link CiDi is defined as two angles, namely, a rotation of θi3 about the fixed z-axis, followed by a rotation of θi2 about the fixed x-axis. Thus, the rotation matrix is (3)oRci=Rot(x,θi2)Rot(z,θi3)=[cθi3-sθi30sθi3cθi2cθi3cθi2-sθi2sθi3sθi2cθi3sθi2cθi2]

sec.title: Position analysis
sec.p: The objective of the position analysis is to define a mapping from the position of the sliding ram to the set of joint angles that achieve that position. For this analysis, the position of the sliding ram is considered known.

As shown in Figure 2, the closed-loop position equation associated with each limb can be written as (4)rAi+ai+bi+ci+di=rO1+ei(i=1,2,3,4) (5)rO1+d5+c5+b5=rM1+m1+g1 (6)rM1+m1+h1=rO2+l1 (7)rM2+m2+h2=rO2+l2 (8)rM1+m1+g1=rM2+m2+g2 where rAi=[xAi yAi 0]T,rO1=[x1 y1 z1]T, rO2=[0 0 z2]T, ei=Rot(x,θ6)[1xEi 1yEi0]T=[1xEi 1yEicθ61yEisθ6]T, ai=Rot(x,θi1)[0a0]T=[0 acθi1asθi1]T,bi=Rot(x,θi2)[0b0]T=[0bcθi2bsθi2]T, ci=Rot(x,θi2)Rot(z,θi3)[0c0]T=[ccθi3csθi3cθi2csθi3sθi2]T, di=Rot(x,θi2)[0d0]T=[0dcθi2dsθi2]T,b5=Rot(x,θ52)[0lb0]T=[0lbcθ52lbsθ52]T, c5=Rot(x,θ52)Rot(z,θ53)[0lc0]T=[lccθ53lcsθ53cθ52lcsθ53sθ52]T, d5=Rot(x,θ52)[0ld0]T=[0ldcθ52ldsθ52]T,(i=1,2,3,4) gj=Rot(x,θj7)[0lg0]T=[0lgcθj7lgsθj7]T,hj=Rot(x,θj8)[0lh0]T=[0lhcθj8lhsθj8]T, mj=Rot(x,θj9)[0lm0]T=[0lmcθj9lmsθj9]T, rMj=[0yMjzMj]T,lj=[02yHj0]T,(j=1,2) and a, b, c, d, lb, lc, ld, lm, lg, and lh denote the lengths of links AiBi, BiCi, CiDi, DiEi, B5C5, C5D5, D5E5, MjGj, GjB5, and GjHj, respectively.

Based on equations (6) to (8), the position vector of joint point B5 is (9)rB5=[xB5 yB5 zB5]T=[0 yM1+lmcosθ19+lgcosθ17zM1+lmsinθ19+lgsinθ17]T where θ19=2tan-1k2-k1 2+k2 2-k3 2k1-k3, θ29=2tan-1k5+k4 2+k5 2-k6 2k4-k6, θ17=2tan-1k8-k7 2+k8 2-k9 2k7-k9, k1=-2lm(2yH1-yM1),k2=-2lm(z2-zM1),k3=(2yH1-yM1)2+lm 2+(z2-zM1)2-lh 2, k4=-2lm(2yH2-yM2),k5=-2lm(z2-zM2),k6=(2yH2-yM2)2+lm 2+(z2-zM2)2-lh 2, k7=2lg(yM1-yM2+lmcθ19-lmcθ29),k8=2lg(zM1-zM2+lmsθ19-lmsθ29),k9=(yM1-yM2+lmcθ19-lmcθ29)2 +(zM1-zM2+lmsθ19-lmsθ29)2,

One can see that yB5 and zB5 are the functions of variable z2. This means that for prescribed values of the position of the sliding ram, the joint coordinate B5 possesses one solution under one specific assemble configuration.
From equation (5), the constraint equation between joint point B5 and moving platform is (10)[(y1-yB5)2+(z1-zB5)2-(lb+ld)2-(lc 2-x1 2)]2=4(lb+ld)2(lc 2-x1 2)

This means there are an infinite number of solutions for the position of moving platform for a given position of joint point B5. Moreover, the orientation of moving platform is not constrained by the passive limb. On the other hand, while the pose of moving platform is specified, the position of the sliding ram is decided.

Solving equation (4), the inverse kinematics analysis produces a set of three joint angles for each active limb that define the possible configuration for each limb for the given pose of the moving platform. (11)θi1=2tan-1k11±k10 2+k11 2-k12 2k10-k12 (12)θi2=2tan-1k14∓k13 2+k14 2-k15 2k13-k15 (13)θi3=cos-1x1+1xEi-xAici where k10=2a(y1+1yEicosθ6-yAi)k11=2a(z1+1yEisinθ6)k12=(b+csinθi3+d)2-(y1+1yEicosθ6-yAi)2 -(z1+1yEisinθ6)2-a2 k13=2(b+csinθi3+d)(y1+1yEicosθ6-yAi)k14=2(b+csinθi3+d)(z1+1yEisinθ6)k15=a2-(y1+1yEicosθ6-yAi)2 -(z1+1yEisinθ6)2-(b+csinθi3+d)2
Hence, for a given pose of the moving platform, there are two possible configurations for each limb according to the assembly condition of moving platform shown in Figure 1.

From above position analysis, one can know that there are infinite solutions for the active limb to a prescribed position of the sliding ram. It is necessary to apply an approach to choose an actuation scheme from all available solutions. To find an optimal solution, different cost functions may be defined for different purposes such as minimum energy, distance, time, or condition number.30 Here, the optimization method is based on the force transmissibility performance between two branches of the passive limb. In this mechanism, since each actuator has an independent motion, the moving platform can asymmetrically transmit the force to the two branches of the toggle mechanism in the passive limb, in spite of the geometric symmetric arrangement of the toggle mechanism. This will inevitably produce lateral forces acting on the guide way of the ram. To overcome this situation, a reasonable actuation scheme is defined as follows. One motion called motion A is imposed to the links A1B1 and A2B2, that is, θ11 = θ21 = θA. Meanwhile, the other motion called motion B is exerted on the links A3B3 and A4B4, that is, θ31 = θ41 = θB. The relationship between motions A and B is expressed as (14) {θA+θB=π0≤θA<πθA+θB=3ππ≤θA<2π

According to this input planning method, the active limbs and moving platform always keep symmetric about the O–xz plane. Moreover, the link B5C5D5E5 in passive limb is parallel to the z-axis. It can be proofed that the vector of pose of moving platform is simplified to [0 0 z1 0]T using such input motion planning. Such configuration can transmit the force symmetrically to the two branches of the toggle mechanism in the passive limb. The lateral forces acting on the guide way of the ram do not happen.

sec.title: Velocity analysis
sec.p: The angular velocity of each link is derived by differentiating the loop closure equation for each limb and then solving the resulting system of equations in terms of generalized velocity. Then, the Jacobian matrix that maps the joint velocity to the generalized velocity can be determined.

Taking the derivative of equation (4) with respect to time gives (15)x·1=-θ·i3csθi3 (16)y·1-θ·6 1yEisθ6=-θ·i1asθi1+θ·i3ccθi3cθi2 -θ·i2(b+csθi3+d)sθi2 (17)z·1+θ·6 1yEicθ6=θ·i1acθi1+θ·i3ccθi3sθi2 +θ·i2(b+csθi3+d)cθi2

Then, the matrix that maps the joint velocity to the generalized moving platform velocity can be determined (18)[θ·i1θ·i2θ·i3]=Ji[x·1y·1z·1θ·6]. where Ji=Jθi -1Jpi Jθi=[asθi3s(θi2-θi1) 0 00 (b+csθi3+d)s(θi1-θi2)sθi3 00 0 -csθi3] Jpi=[ cθi3 cθi2sθi3 sθi2sθi3 1yEisθi3s(θi2-θ6)cθi3c(θi2-θi1) cθi1sθi3 sθi1sθi3 1yEis(θi1-θ6)sθi3 1 0 0 0]

In the same way, taking the derivative of equations (5) to (8) with respect to time yields (19)z·2=J5[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (20)[θ·52θ·53]=J6[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (21)[θ·j7θ·j8θ·j9]=J7j[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T where J5=1R1cθ52+R2sθ52[cθ53sθ53 cθ52 sθ52 0] J6=[R2cθ53cθ52-R1cθ53sθ52sθ53R3R2R3-R1R301lcsθ53000] J7j=J8jJ5 J8j=[(sθ28s(θj7-θ29) ×s(θ18-θ19) -sθ18s(θj7-θ19)×s(θ28-θ29))(lgs(θ27-θ17) ×s(θ18-θ19) ×s(θ28-θ29))sθj9lhs(θj9-θj8)sθj8lms(θj8-θj9)]T R1=-sθ18sθ19s(θ18-θ19)-sθ28sθ17s(θ27-θ29)s(θ28-θ29)s(θ27-θ17) +sθ18sθ17s(θ27-θ19)s(θ18-θ19)s(θ27-θ17) R2=sθ18cθ19s(θ18-θ19)+sθ28cθ17s(θ27-θ29)s(θ28-θ29)s(θ27-θ17) -sθ18cθ17s(θ27-θ19)s(θ18-θ19)s(θ27-θ17) R3=(lb+lcsθ53+ld)(R1cθ52+R2sθ53)

sec.title: Acceleration analysis
sec.p: Acceleration analysis can be performed by second order differentiating equations (4) to (8) with respect to time. The results for acceleration analysis are directly presented as follows.

Based on equation (4), the angular acceleration of links in active limbs are derived in the form of matrix (22)[θ··i1θ··i2θ··i3]=Ji[x··1y··1z··1θ··6]+Vi where Vi=Jθi -1[vi1 vi2 vi3]T vi1=θ·i1 2ac(θi1-θi2)sθi3+θ·i2 2(b+csθi3+d)sθi3 +θ·i3 2c-θ·6 21yEic(θ6-θi2)sθi3 vi2=θ·i1 2asθi3+θ·i2 2(b+csθi3+d)c(θi1-θi2)sθi3 +θ·i3 2cc(θi2-θi1)-θ·6 21 yEic(θ6-θi1)sθi3 vi3=θ·i3 2ccθi3

sec.title: Velocity and acceleration of the mass center of each link
sec.p: Let q·=[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T be the vector of generalized velocity. The velocities of mass center of each link can be expressed as a function of q· by means of Jacobian matrices. It is assumed that the mass of each link in this model is uniformly distributed along the length and the center of mass is located at the center of the link. The position vector of the center of link AiBi is (32)rai=rAi+ai2

The linear velocity of the center is found by taking the derivative of the equation with respect to time, and written in matrix form (33)vai=ωai×ai2=Jai[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T where (34)ωai=[θ·i100]T,Jai=12[0-asθi1a>cθi1][Ji,1]1×4 and where Ji,1 is the first row of Ji, and Jai is a 3 × 4 matrix. Taking the derivative of equation (8) with respect to time gives (35)v·ai=ω·ai×ai2+ωai×(ωai×ai2) where ω·ai=[θ··i1 0 0]T

For link BiCi, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (36)rbi=rAi+ai+bi2 (37)vbi=ωai×ai+ωbi×bi2=Jbi[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (38)v·bi=ω·ai×ai+ωai×(ωai×ai)+ω·bi×bi2+ωbi×(ωbi×bi2) where ωbi=[θ·i2 0 0]T, ω·bi=[θ··i2 0 0]T,and Jbi=[0-asθi1a>cθi1][Ji,1]1×4+12[0-bsθi2b>cθi2][Ji,2]1×4

For link CiDi, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (39)rci=rAi+ai+bi+ci2 (40)vci=ωai×ai+ωbi×bi+ωci×ci2 =Jci[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (41)v·ci=ω·ai×ai+ωai×(ωai×ai)+ω·bi×bi+ωbi×(ωbi×bi)+ω·ci×ci2+ωci×(ωci×ci2) where ωci=[θ·i2 0 θ·i3]T, ω·ci=[θ··i2 0 θ··i3]T, Jci=[0-asθi1a>cθi1][Ji,1]1×4+[0-bsθi2b>cθi2][Ji,2]1×4 +12[ 0 -ccθi3cθi2-ccθi3sθi2 -csθi3ccθi3cθi2 0][Ji,2Ji,3]2×4

For link DiEi, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (42)rdi=rAi+ai+bi+ci+di2 (43)vdi=ωai×ai+ωbi×bi+ωci×ci+ωdi×di2 =Jdi[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (44)v·di=ω·ai×ai+ωai×(ωai×ai)+ω·bi×bi +ωbi×(ωbi×bi)+ω·ci×ci+ωci×(ωci×ci) +ω·di×di2+ωdi×(ωdi×di2) where ωdi=[θ·i2 0 0]T, ω·di=[θ··i2 0 0]T, Jdi=[0-asθi1acθi1][Ji,1]1×4+[0-bsθi2bcθi2][Ji,2]1×4 +[ 0 -ccθi3cθi2-ccθi3sθi2 -csθi3ccθi3cθi2 0][Ji,2Ji,3]2×4 +12[0-dsθi2dcθi2][Ji,2]1×4

For link E5D5, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (45)rd5=rO1+d52 (46)vd5=vO1+ωd5×d52=Jd5[x·1 y·1 z·1θ·6]T (47)v·d5=v·O1+ω·d5×d52+ωd5×(ωd5×d52) where ωd5=[θ·52 0 0]T, ω·d5=[θ··52 0 0]T Jd5=[E3×3 03×1]+12[0-ldsθ52ldcθ52][J6,1]1×4 and E3×3 is a 3 × 3 identity matrix.

For link D5C5, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (48)rc5=rO1+d5+c52 (49)vc5=vO1+ωd5×d5+ωc5×c52 =Jc5[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (50)v·c5=v·O1+ω·d5×d5+ωd5×(ωd5×d5) +ω·c5×c52+ωc5×(ωc5×c52) where ωc5=[θ·52 0 θ·53]T, ω·c5=[θ··52 0 θ··53]T Jc5=[E3×3 03×1]+[ 0-ldsθ52ldcθ52][J6,1]1×4 +12[ 0 -lccθ53cθ52-lccθ53sθ52 -lcsθ53lccθ53cθ52 0][J6,1J6,2]2×4,

For link C5B5, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (51)rb5=rO1+d5+c5+b52 (52)vb5=vO1+ωd5×d5+ωc5×c5 +ωb5×b52=Jb5[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (53)v·b5=v·O1+ω·d5×d5+ωd5×(ωd5×d5) +ω·c5×c5+ωc5×(ωc5×c5) +ω·b5×b52+ωb5×(ωb5×b52) where ωb5=[θ·52 0 0]T, ω·b5=[θ··52 0 0]T Jb5=[E3×3 03×1]+[ 0-ldsθ52ldcθ52][J6,1]1×4 +[ 0 -lccθ53cθ52-lccθ53sθ52 -lcsθ53lccθ53cθ52 0][J6,1J6,2]2×4 +12[0-lbsθ52lbcθ52][J6,1]1×4

For link MjGj, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (54)rmj=rMj+mj2 (55)vmj=ωmj×mj2=Jmj[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (56)v·mj=ω·mj×mj2+ωmj×(ωmj×mj2) where ωmj=[θ·j9 0 0]T, ω·mj=[θ··j9 0 0]T Jmj=12[0-lmsθj9lmcθj9][J7j,3]1×4

For link GjB5, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (57)rgj=rMj+mj+gj2 (58)vgj=ωmj×mj+ωgj×gj2=Jgj[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (59)v·gj=ω·mj×mj+ωmj×(ωmj×mj) +ω·gj×gj2+ωgj×(ωgj×gj2) where ωgj=[θ·j7 0 0]T, ω·gj=[θ··j7 0 0]T, Jgj=[0-lmsθj9lmcθj9][J7j,3]1×4+12[0-lgsθj7lgcθj7][J7j,1]1×4

For link GjHj, the vector of position, linear velocity, and acceleration of the mass center are (60)rhj=rMj+mj+hj2 (61)vhj=ωmj×mj+ωhj×hj2=Jhj[x·1 y·1 z·1 θ·6]T (62)v·hj=ω·mj×mj+ωmj×(ωmj×mj) +ω·hj×hj2+ωhj×(ωhj×hj2) where ωhj=[θ·j8 0 0]T, ·ωhj=[θ··j8 0 0]T, Jhj=[0-lmsθj9lmcθj9][J7j,3]1×4+12[0-lhsθj8lhcθj8][J7j,2]1×4

sec.title: Dynamics
sec.p: The input forces required to produce a desired trajectory of the sliding ram with nominal capacity are more crucial to design of the control law or the estimation of servomotor parameters for the mechanical press. To achieve this goal, the dynamical equations of motion are formulated by the principle of virtual work. The approach described here leads to efficient algorithms, since the constraint forces and moments of the system have been eliminated from the equations of motion and there is no differential equation for the whole procedure.

sec.title: Forces and torques on moving parts
sec.p: Assuming that the gravitational force is the only external force, according to the D’Alembert’s principle, the force acting on the center of mass of each moving part consists of two parts: the inertial and the gravity forces. Similarly, the moment acting on each moving part is the inertial moment. Assume there is no frictional force for the whole robot system. The resultant of the forces and torques exerted at the center of mass of the moving part is (63)Fpart=[fpartnpart]=[ mpartg-mpartv·part-oIpartω·part-ωpart×(oIpartωpart)] where fpart and npart are the force and moment exerted at the center of mass of the moving part, respectively. oIpart=oRpartIpart oRpart T is the inertia matrix of the moving part taken about the center of mass expressed in the O–xyz coordinate system, v·part the linear acceleration of the center of mass, and ωpart and ω·part the angular velocity and acceleration, respectively. mpart is its mass and g = [0 0 9.81]T m2/s is the gravitational acceleration vector. Noted that the moving parts include links AiBi, BiCi, CiDi, DiEi, B5C5, C5D5, D5E5, MjGj, GjB5, GjHj and moving platform and the subscript part denote ai, bi, ci, di, mj, hj, gj, and O1.

In particular, there is pure translational motion for the sliding ram, so the resultant of the forces exerted at the center of mass of the sliding ram can be expressed in the O–xyz coordinate system as (64)Q=m2g-m2v·2 where m2 and v·2=[0 0 z··2]T are the mass and the acceleration of the sliding ram, respectively.

sec.title: Dynamic model
sec.p: According to the D’Alembert’s principle, the principle of the virtual work can be extended from the static to the dynamic case. It can be stated as: the virtual work of the external forces applied to the system must be zero. For this manipulator, it can be expressed in the formula (65)δθTT+δq2 TF+δq2 TQ+δqo1 Tfo1+δθo1 Tno1+δqb5 Tfb5+δθb5 Tnb5+δqc5 Tfc5+δθc5 Tnc5+δqd5 Tfd5+δθd5 Tnd5+∑i=1 4 (δqai Tfai+δθai Tnai+δqbi Tfbi+δθbi Tnbi+δqci Tfci +δθci Tnci+δqdi Tfdi+δθdi Tndi )+∑j=1 2 (δqmj Tfmj+δθmj Tnmj+δqhj Tfhj +δθhj Tnhj+δqgj Tfgj+δθgj Tngj )=0

It is noted that the input forces T = [τ1 τ2 τ3 τ4]T acted on joints Ai and the applied force F = [0 0 fo]T acted on the sliding ram are intentionally isolated from the other forces for the convenience of derivation. The forces fpart, torques npart and their corresponding virtual displacements δqpart, δθpart are expressed in the O-xyz coordinate system. The virtual displacements in equation (64) must be compatible with the kinematic constraints imposed by the joints. Therefore, there are relationships between the above virtual displacements and the generalized virtual displacement δq = [δx1 δy1 δz1 δθ6]T as follows (66)δθ=[δθ11 δθ21 δθ31 δθ41]T=[J1,1J2,1J3,1J4,1]4×4δq=Ji1δq (67)δq2=[0 0 δz2]T=[02×4J5]3×4δq (68)δqo1=[δx1 δy1 δz1]T=[E3×3 03×1]3×4δq (69)δθo1=[δθ6 0 0]T=[01×3 102×3 02×1]3×4δq (70)δqai=[δxai δyai δzai]T=Jaiδq (71)δθai=[δθi1 0 0]T=[Ji,102×4]3×4δq (72)δqbi=[δxbi δybi δzbi]T=Jbiδq (73)δθbi=[δθi2 0 0]T=[Ji,202×4]3×4δq (74)δqci=[δxci δyci δzci]T=Jciδq (75)δθci=[δθi2 0 δθi3]T=[Ji,201×4Ji,3]3×4δq (76)δqdi=[δxdi δydi δzdi]T=Jdiδq (77)δθdi=[δθi2 0 0]T=[Ji,202×4]3×4δq (78)δqmj=[δxmj δymj δzmj]T=Jmjδq (79)δθmj=[δθj9 0 0]T=[J7j,302×4]3×4δq (80)δqhj=[δxhj δyhj δzhj]T=Jhjδq (81)δθhj=[δθj8 0 0]T=[J7j,202×4]3×4δq (82)δqgj=[δxgj δygj δzgj]T=Jgjδq (83)δθgj=[δθj7 0 0]T=[J7j,102×4]3×4δq

By observing equations (65) to (83), there are four unknown quantities (τi i = 1, 2, 3, 4) in the four linear consistent equations. There is no actuation redundancy. Since equation (65) is always valid for any δq, when Ji1 is not in a singular, the input torque can be determined (84)T=-Ji1 -T { [02×4J5 ]T (F+Q )+ [E3×3 03×1 ]Tfo1 + [01×3 102×3 02×1 ]Tno1+Jb5 Tfb5 + [J6,102×4 ]Tnb5+Jc5 Tfc5+ [J6,101×4J6,2 ]Tnc5 +Jd5 Tfd5+ [J6,102×4 ]Tnd5 +∑i=1 4 (Jai Tfai+ [Ji,102×4 ]Tnai+Jbi Tfbi+ [Ji,202×4 ]Tnbi +Jci Tfci+ [Ji,201×4Ji,3 ]Tnci+Jdi Tfdi+ [Ji,202×4 ]Tndi ) +∑j=1 2 (Jmj Tfmj+ [J7j,302×4 ]Tnmj+Jhj Tfhj+ [J7j,202×4 ]Tnhj +Jgj Tfgj+ [J7j,102×4 ]Tngj ) }

From equation (84), it is shown that the input torques are determined by the structure parameters, the position parameters, the kinematics parameters (including the velocity and the acceleration), the gravity term and the term caused by the external force exerted at the sliding ram.

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p:
In this section, a numerical example with heavy duty for the driving toque computation of the mechanical press is presented. The program based on the algorithm is developed using the MATLAB software. The parameters of the mechanical press used for the simulation are based on the design criteria as follows: (a) maximum ram travel is 1200 mm; (b) nominal capacity is 25,000 kN; (c) travel of drawing process is 300 mm; (d) Stroke number is 20 r/min, which are given in Tables 1 to 3. The masses of the moving platform and sliding ram are mO1 = 12,000 kg and m2 = 100,000 kg. The length parameters are chosen by searching method to ensure maximum ram travel. The mass parameters are decided by referring to the corresponding part of mechanical presses in use with the same capacity. Since the mass of link mlink is supposed uniformly distributed along the length, the inertia parameters used in the simulation are given as follows. In addition, each link does not spin about its longitudinal axis, the corresponding inertia parameter is set as zero (85)Ilink=[mlinkllink 212 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 mlinkllink 212]kg·m2 Table 1.
The joint point locations on the fixed platform (m).
A1 A2 A3 A4 M1 M2
x −1.000 1.000 1.000 −1.000 0 0
y 1.200 1.100 −1.100 −1.200 1.300 −1.300
z 0 0 0 0 0.500 0.500
Table 2.
The joint point locations on the moving platform and sliding ram in the coordinate frame o1–x1y1z1 and o2–x2y2z2 (m).
1E1 1E2 1E3 1E4 2H1 2H2
x −1.000 1.000 1.000 −1.000 0 0
y 1.200 1.100 −1.100 −1.200 1.600 −1.600
z 0 0 0 0 0 0
Table 3.
The length and mass parameters of the links.
AiBi BiCi CiDi DiEi B5C5 C5D5 D5E5 MjGj GjB5 GjHj
Length (m) 0.360 0.800 0.30414 0.200 0.200 0.200 0.200 1.700 0.868 1.600
Mass (kg) 900 400 600 400 1000 2000 1000 2300 1200 2000

In general, the forming process can be divided into three phases: rapid approach, working motion, and rapid return. A typical deep-drawing process is used in the numerical simulation. The motion of the sliding ram is expressed as a function of time by cubic spline as follows (86)s= {-5.7985714t3+5.6592857t2 tε[0,0.5s ]3.3468254(t-0.5)3-3.0385714(t-0.5)2 +1.3103571(t-0.5)+0.6900 tε[0.5s,0.8s ]-0.07579365(t-0.8)3-0.02642857(t-0.8)2 +0.3908571(t-0.8)+0.9000 tε[0.8s,2.0s ]-2.000(t-2)3-0.300(t-2)2+1.2 tε[2.0s,2.5s ]6.800(t-2.5)3-3.300(t-2.5)2 -1.8000(t-2.5)+0.87500 tε[2.5s,3.0s ]

Moreover, the stroke, velocity, and acceleration of the sliding ram with regard to time are shown in Figure 3. According to the trajectory of sliding ram and actuation scheme discussed in section ‘Position analysis’, there are two cases of input motions, which are related to the rotation direction of links AiBi. The two cases of variations of angular position of the active links AiBi are shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. Figure 3.
Variations of sliding ram stroke (a), velocity and acceleration (b) vs. time. Figure 4.
Variations of angular position of the active links AiBi vs. time in two input cases.

According to equation (83), while the mechanical press is operating without the external force exerted at the sliding ram, the whole actuating torques, the torques caused by the sliding ram and links can be computed for two input cases. The results are shown in Figures 5 and 6, respectively. The common characteristic in two cases is that for this simulation the input torques at joints A1 and A2 are equal to each other, and those at joints A3 and A4 are also equal to one another, and the torques caused by the sliding ram term are much larger than the links term. The differences between two cases are obvious. For case I, the torques required in the course of rapid return are larger than those of rapid approach. The situation in case II is on the contrary. Moreover, the maximum torque required in case I is smaller than that of case II. Figure 5.
Variations of total torques (a), torques caused by sliding ram (b), torques caused by links (c) vs. time in input case I. Figure 6.
Variations of total torques (a), torques caused by sliding ram (b), torques caused by links (c) vs. time in input case II.

In order to properly size the actuators, the external force on the sliding ram is exerted according to the nominal capacity of 25,000 kN, as shown in Figure 7. The required torques for two input cases are computed, and the results are plotted in Figure 8. As can be seen from Figure 8, input torques at joints A1 and A2 are equal to each other, and those at joints A3 and A4 are also equal to one another. Their absolute values are the same at any instant. Moreover, the required torques for case II are much larger than those for case I. The two steep changes of the input torques between t = 0.5 s and t = 1.0 s in two input cases are due to the impulsive external force exerted on the sliding ram at the corresponding position of 300 mm above the bottom dead point. Figure 7.
Nominal capacity with respect to the position of sliding ram. Figure 8.
Required torque for nominal capacity vs. time for two input cases.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: For the purpose of the development of high-capacity mechanical presses, this article proposes a new type of mechanical press with parallel topology. Four servomotors actuate different limbs of parallel mechanism to realize the multiple actuations without causing actuation redundancy. The pose variables of moving platform are chosen as generalized coordinates to describe the manipulator system. By means of input motion planning, a mapping from the position of the sliding ram to the set of actuated joint angles is decided and two input cases are illustrated. The linear form of dynamic model is derived by the principle of virtual work and the concept of link Jacobian matrices. A typical deep-drawing process with nominal 25,000 kN capacity and 1200 mm stroke is simulated and the required driving torques are computed for two input cases. The results of simulation imply that each actuator afford the same size of torque that are cause by the inertial forces and moment, the gravity force and external force exerted at the sliding ram. Moreover, the rotation directions of the input links AiBi make a significant impact on the maximum value of driving torques. These performance analyses provide a basis to design of the control law or the estimation of servomotor parameters for the mechanical press.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC Grant No. 50875161), partially by the National Science and Technology Major Project (Grant Nos 2010ZX04017-013 and 2010ZX04004-112).
